data.title: New York City: Top 20 Artists Deeply Connected to The Big Apple
data.meta_description: Delve into the connection between New York City and 20 artists who have left a lasting impact on the city's music scene.
data.text:
New York City is an epicenter for creativity and culture in the world. It has produced some of the most influential and successful music artists of all time. From hip-hop to country, here's a list of 20 music artists who made a significant impact on NYC's music scene

1. Bob Dylan

Bob Dylan is a legendary songwriter and performer who was born and raised in Duluth, Minnesota. However, he moved to New York City in the early 1960s and became one of the city's most influential musicians. Dylan's career took off in the folk music scene, and he soon became one of the leading voices of the anti-war and civil rights movements.

His powerful lyrics and unique singing style have earned him numerous awards and accolades, including the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016. Dylan's impact on the music world cannot be overstated, and he remains one of the most influential musicians of all time. From "Blowin' in the Wind" to "Like a Rolling Stone" Dylan's songs continue to inspire and captivate audiences around the world.

2. Madonna

Madonna Louise Ciccone was born on August 16th, 1958 in Bay City, Michigan. She moved to NYC at the age of 20, making it her home base ever since. Madonna is one of the most successful solo acts in music history and has sold over 300 million records worldwide. Her greatest songs include "Like a Virgin", "Vogue" and "Like a Prayer".

Madonna was an integral part of the NYC music scene in the 1980s, a time when punk, rock, hip-hop, disco and house all had an influence. She remains an icon and inspiration to many in the city.

3. Billy Joel

Born in The Bronx and grew up on Long Island, Billy Joel is one of the best-selling musicians of all time. He is known for exploring genres such as rock, pop and classical. He is one of the most influential songwriters in history, with hits like “Piano Man”, “We Didn’t Start the Fire”, and “Uptown Girl”.

Joel has won 6 Grammy Awards and has sold over 150 million records worldwide and he was inducted into both the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame (1999) and the Long Island Music Hall of Fame (2006).

4. Frank Sinatra

Frank Sinatra, also known as "Ol' Blue Eyes" was born in Hoboken, New Jersey in 1915 but he is deeply connected to New York City, where he spent much of his life and career (and where he bought a penthouse in 1961).

He was a major part of the music scene for decades, and is still considered to be one of the most iconic singers of all time. He started out in the jazz scene, and then moved onto the big band, swing and bop era. Some of his most famous songs include “Summer Wind”, “My Way” and “New York, New York”.

5. John Lennon

John Lennon is undoubtedly one of the most famous musicians to have ever lived, and his time in New York City was a major part of his artistic journey. After the break-up of The Beatles, Lennon moved to New York City with his wife Yoko Ono in 1971. He recorded several albums during his time there, including "Imagine" and "Mind Games", and was an outspoken advocate for peace and social justice.

Lennon's life was tragically cut short in 1980 when he was murdered outside his apartment building in Manhattan, but his music and message continue to inspire generations of fans around the world.

6. Louis Armstrong

Louis Armstrong, also known as "Satchmo" is widely considered as one of the most influential musicians in the 20th century. He was a trumpeter, singer, and composer who rose to fame in the 1920s and 1930s with his unique style and distinctive sound we can find in songs as "What a Wonderful World" and "La Vie en Rose"

Armstrong first arrived in New York in 1924 and quickly established himself as a prominent figure in the city's vibrant jazz scene. He performed at numerous venues, including the Cotton Club and the Savoy Ballroom.

7. Barbra Streisand

Barbra Streisand is one of the greatest female singers of all time and an iconic figure in American popular culture. She was born and raised in Brooklyn, New York City, and rose to fame in the 1960s with her powerful voice and stunning performances.

She has performed at venues like Madison Square Garden and Central Park and she has received numerous awards and accolades for her contributions to music, including two Academy Awards, ten Grammy Awards, five Emmy Awards and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Streisand has also been an active philanthropist, supporting environmental causes, civil rights protection and women's health issues.

8. Paul Simon

Paul Simon is a singer-songwriter born in Newark, New Jersey and grew up in Queens, New York. He rose to fame in the 1960s as half of the iconic duo Simon & Garfunkel, with whom helped to define the sound of a generation with their classic songs, including "The Sound of Silence","Bridge Over Troubled Water" and "Mrs. Robinson".

He is a 16-time Grammy Award Winner and is considered to be one of the best songwriters of all time. His musical style often incorporates world music and folk elements, and his songs are often inspired by the city he loves.

9. Leonard Cohen

Leonard Cohen was a Canadian singer, songwriter and poet who spent a significant portion of his life and career in New York City. In the 1960s, he relocated to the city to pursue his music career and became an integral part of the thriving folk scene in Greenwich Village.

During his time in the city, he developed close relationships with many influential musicians, writers and artists, and became well-known for his haunting and introspective songwriting.

10. Lou Reed

Lou Reed was one of the founding members of the legendary rock band The Velvet Underground. Born in Brooklyn in 1942, Reed grew up in Long Island before moving to Manhattan in the 1960s. He went on to release a string of solo albums and became one of the most influential figures in the punk and alternative rock scenes.

Reed's connection to New York City is deeply intertwined with his music and his image. He sang about the city's gritty streets, its drug culture, and its underground music scene in songs like "Walk on the Wild Side" and "Sweet Jane". Reed's music continues to embody the spirit of the city and its residents, capturing the grit, determination, and individuality that makes New York City so special.

11. Jay-Z

Hailing from the Marcy Projects in Brooklyn, Shawn Corey Carter, better known as JAY-Z, has been a major player in the music industry ever since. He has released 13 solo albums, which have sold millions of copies worldwide. He received 24 Grammy Awards and is one of the best selling music artists of all time.

From revitalizing the legendary Def Jam Recordings to launching his own record label - Roc Nation, Jay-Z has had a tremendous impact on the NYC music scene. Some of his most famous songs include “99 Problems”, “Empire State of Mind” and “Big Pimpin’”.

12. Lady Gaga

Born in 1986, Lady Gaga was raised in Manhattan and began performing in the city’s music clubs at open mic nights. She has achieved a level of success like no other female artist in history. Her albums “The Fame” and “Born This Way”, have sold millions of copies worldwide. Some of her most iconic songs include “Poker face” and “Bad Romance”.

Lady Gaga’s immense success is owed to her unique style and strong presence on social media. She has remained active on the NYC music scene, and continues to inspire young artists.

13. Mariah Carey

Mariah Carey was born in Huntington, Long Island, and she quickly became known for her powerful voice, five-octave range (which earned her the name "Songbird Supreme"), and versatility as a performer, captivating audiences with her pop and R&B ballads.

She is currently the best-selling female artist of all time, with 19 number one singles on the Billboard Hot 100. She wrote some of the biggest hits of the 1990s and 2000s, including “We Belong Together”, “All I Want For Christmas Is You” and “Hero”.

14. Jennifer Lopez

Jennifer Lopez, also known as J Lo, was born and raised in the Bronx, New York City. She began her entertainment career as a dancer, and rose to prominence in the late 1990s as a singer and actress.

Throughout her career, Lopez has maintained a strong connection to New York City, often referencing her upbringing in the Bronx in her music and performances such as "Jenny From The Block". She has also been a passionate advocate for the city's Latin American community, and has used her platform Limitless Labs to raise awareness for various social and political issues.

15. Nicki Minaj

Nicki Minaj, born Onika Tanya Maraj, is a hip-hop artist, singer and songwriter. She grew up in Queens, New York in a working-class household and developed a love for hip-hop and rap music at a young age.

She gained fame after releasing mixtapes in 2007 and has since become one of the most successful female rap artists of all time. She released five studio albums and received multiple Grammy Award nominations. Her hits include “Super Bass”, “Anaconda”, “Starships” and “The Night is Still Young”.

16. Deborah Harry

Deborah Harry was the lead singer of the influential New Wave band Blondie, which was one of the most popular and innovative groups to emerge from the New York City music scene in the 1970s. With her distinctive voice and stylish image, Harry helped to define the sound and look of punk and New Wave music.

Blondie had numerous hits during their peak years, including "Heart of Glass", "Call Me" and "The Tide is High", and they continue to tour and record to this day. Harry has also pursued a successful solo career, releasing several critically acclaimed albums and collaborating with numerous other musicians.

17. 50 Cent

50 Cent, born Curtis James Jackson III, is a rapper and entrepreneur hailing from Queens, New York City. He rose to fame in the early 2000s with his critically acclaimed debut album "Get Rich or Die Tryin'" and has since become one of the most successful hip-hop artists of all time.

Throughout his career, 50 Cent has never forgotten his roots and has consistently paid homage to his hometown of New York City, especially his birthplace of Queens. He often raps about growing up in the borough, and many of his tracks feature references to the city's streets and neighborhoods.

18. Liza Minnelli

Born in Hollywood, California, Liza Minnelli grew up in the limelight and began performing at a young age. However, it was her connection to New York City that solidified her place as a legendary performer. Minnelli rose to fame in the 1960s and 1970s, performing in some of the most prestigious venues in the city, including Carnegie Hall and the Radio City Music Hall.

She also appeared in several Broadway productions, including the original productions of "Flora the Red Menace" and "The Act".

19. Alicia Keys

Alicia Keys is a Grammy-winning R&B and soul singer-songwriter who was born and raised in the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City. From a young age, Keys showed a natural talent for music and began playing classical piano at the age of 6.

Her musical roots run deep in New York City as she honed her skills at the Professional Performing Arts School and later at Columbia University. As a native New Yorker, she has been heavily influenced by the city's diverse cultural and musical heritage, which is reflected in her soulful, jazzy, and hip-hop-infused sound.

20. Cardi B

Cardi B, born Belcalis Marlenis Almánzar Cephus in the South Bronx, New York City, is a rapper and singer who rose to fame through social media platforms. She is known for her bold, confident, and unapologetic style, which reflects her upbringing in the tough streets of the South Bronx.

Her lyrics often tell stories of growing up in the city and the struggles she faced, which have struck a chord with audiences around the world. From her breakout hit "Bodak Yellow" to "I Like It" featuring Bad Bunny and J Balvin, Cardi B has become one of the most successful female rappers of all time and a true representative of New York City's rich hip-hop heritage.

New York City has a rich and diverse music scene that has produced some of the biggest and most talented artists in the world. From Barbra Streisand to Jay-Z, these 20 artists have all made their mark on the city and its music culture in their own unique way.

Whether they were born and raised in the city or simply found their success and inspiration here, they are all forever tied to the city's rich musical heritage. So, whether you're a die-hard fan of hip-hop, pop, or anything in between, these artists are a must-listen for anyone who loves music and wants to explore the sounds of New York City.
